index.p1: I build moving images that are sharp and emotive. My eye is shaped as much by cinema as by design schools: Villeneuve's precise composition, Burton's playful madness, Nolan's epic scale, and Tarantino's razor-edged rhythm.
index.p2: For me, motion design is about rhythm: shaping beats so the audience knows exactly what to feel and when. Every project starts with the same question: what should the audience feel—and what's the most direct way to show it?

about.lead: Motion Designer & Title Designer. I design sequences that are clear and emotive for film, series, games, and brands.

background.title: Background
background.bio1: At ESDAC I built strong foundations in Graphic Design, focusing on color and observational drawing, thanks to inspiring teachers who shaped the way I still see and build images today. During my apprenticeship at France Sport, I learned to adapt quickly to a professional environment, proving reliable and effective in a fast-moving team.
background.bio2: At ArtFx I sharpened my eye across photography, sculpture, painting, drawing, and film/VFX. Working on many group projects taught me to keep workflows clean, readable, and handoff-ready.
background.bio3: At Objectif3D I developed my 3D skills and studied semiology, learning how images, symbols, and composition guide meaning.
background.bio4: I also studied computer science for two years, which gave me a strong sense of logic and discipline in structuring projects.
background.bio5: Finally, at MJM I brought all of this together in Motion Design — applying everything I had learned — and graduated with honors.

whatido.title: What I do
whatido.item1: Title design & animated typography (main titles, interstitials, on-air graphics)
whatido.item2: 3D-driven spots and graphic sequences (from styleframes to animatics to final renders)
whatido.item3: Hybrid workflows (Cinema 4D/Redshift ↔ After Effects) with clean, disciplined comps
whatido.item4: Editorial clarity: shaping beats so the audience always knows what to feel and when

how.title: How I work
how.step1: Question the brief → <span class='italic'>what should the audience feel?
how.step2: Prove it fast → styleframes and timing tests, no mystery reels.
how.step3: Design for constraints → GPU/RAM, deadlines, local vs. farm render.
how.step4: Name and structure everything → tidy files, handoff-ready projects.
how.step5: Keep it non-destructive → layers, precomps, nodes: always editable, because change will come.

tools.title: Tools
tools.text: Cinema 4D + Redshift, After Effects, Photoshop, Illustrator, X-Particles when needed. Git-based versioning for assets, and a bias toward automation over manual tweaking.

influence.title: Influences
influence.p1: Cinema is my biggest teacher. Denis Villeneuve inspires me for his rhythm, storytelling, and composition. Dune: Part Two was such a reference for me that I even made a project around it during my studies — its sense of scale and control of pacing are masterful. Blade Runner 2049 speaks to my love of cyberpunk, with immaculate visuals and a story that flows like music. Villeneuve is a genius of cinematography — every film he releases seems to claim the Oscar for it.
influence.p2: Tim Burton shaped my taste for playful madness. Beetlejuice (both 1 and 2) with its delirious mix of animatronics and stop motion, and Alice in Wonderland with its sheer fun, show his joy of creation. Yet he can also break your heart, as with Edward Scissorhands. He is a master of both humor and storytelling.
influence.p3: Christopher Nolan is my reference for epic tension. Dunkirk is my favorite: the sound design and relentless pacing make you feel trapped inside the atrocity of war. With The Dark Knight, he mixes suspense, tension, and even humor at the highest level — the Joker remains unforgettable.
influence.p4: Quentin Tarantino is the undisputed master of absurd carnage. Pulp Fiction, Kill Bill, Inglourious Basterds, Once Upon a Time in Hollywood — each shows his talent for rhythm, dialogue, and violence turned into spectacle.
influence.p5: Video games taught me just as much. Cyberpunk 2077 for its storytelling and rhythm, Journey for its visual composition and purity, and Gris for its color, rhythm, immersion, and delicate storytelling. Both Cyberpunk 2077 and Gris even made me cry — proof that when rhythm, image, and narrative align perfectly, motion can reach straight into emotion.
influence.p6: Music is my metronome: from orchestral weight to electronic textures, it dictates the cuts and crescendos in my work.

working.title: Working with me
working.text: Those who worked with me — teachers, mentors, and companies — have praised my adaptability, professionalism, and motivation. My approach is collaborative and clear: pointing out weaknesses is just a step toward making the work stronger.
working.text2: I'm also open to any suggestion that can improve the project, whatever its source. Freelance and remote-friendly, in English or French. Open to international clients and co-direction with studios.

Equinoxe.intro1:
When I joined the project, the logo was already there — but everything else still had to take shape.
My mission was to build the visual foundations of Equinoxe, a Rocket League e-sport association striving to combine professionalism, team spirit, and ambition.
Equinoxe.intro2:
The goal was to craft a cohesive and flexible identity, one that could reflect a serious organization driven by a friendly and motivated community.
I developed a comprehensive design system — color palette, typography, layout structure, components, and media templates — giving the association a clear, consistent, and lasting visual voice.
Equinoxe.intro3:
A refined and balanced direction, true to its name:
Equinoxe, the meeting point between performance and humanity.
Equinoxe.colo1:
The palette is built from the original logo to strengthen Equinoxe's visual DNA.
It draws inspiration from dusk and eclipse tones, the moment where light meets darkness.
Warm and radiant accents contrast with deep, grounded neutrals, balanced by a soft, light tone that brings clarity and finesse.
Equinoxe.colo2:
This choice creates a clean, youthful, and e-sport-driven aesthetic, both professional and visually impactful.
The palette performs well across digital and print, offering clarity, energy, and a bold visual presence, halfway between day and night — like Equinoxe.
Equinoxe.typo1: The typographic system relies on two complementary fonts:
Equinoxe.typo2:
Uni Sans Heavy CAPS — for titles
Bold, structured, and energetic.
Used in all caps, it expresses strength, competitive attitude, and presence.
It is treated as a block, like urban signage — a visual statement, ready to be plastered on a wall.
Equinoxe.typo3:
Noto Sans KR — for body text and digital content
Clean, readable, and modern.
A versatile and unobtrusive typeface that supports the identity without overpowering it, ensuring smooth reading across all formats.
Equinoxe.typo4: Together, they create a balance between punch and clarity, reflecting Equinoxe's dual nature: loud and assertive in its identity, yet structured and professional at its core.
Equinoxe.t2: This set of visuals was designed to ensure clear and consistent communicationaround the competitions Equinoxe takes part in. The goal is to help players, supporters, and partnersfollow the team at a glance: match announcements, live scores, results, and performance highlights.
Equinoxe.t3: I applied Equinoxe's visual identity to a suite of modular, reusable templatestailored for social media. The art direction relies on a controlled typographic hierarchyand a functional color system to distinguish key moments — pre-match, score updates, results, and bracket phases. Together, they form a visual language that iscoherent, efficient, and instantly recognizable.
Equinoxe.twitch2: For Equinoxe's presence on Twitch, I designed a set of visual elements to structure and enhance the streaming experience, including overlays, intermission screens, transitions, and channel panels. The goal was to create a clear, recognizable, and consistent environment aligned with the team's identity, while supporting audience engagement. The layouts focus on readability of key information, seamless integration with gameplay, and an aesthetic tailored to the live format.
Equinoxe.staff2: This series of visuals was designed to communicate roster updates within Equinoxe, including player departures, new signings, staff arrivals, and full roster announcements. The goal was to give these updates a strong and consistent visual identity, whether published in 1:1 or 16:9 formats. These templates present team changes in a way that is professional, structured, and instantly recognizable across social media.
Equinoxe.ccl: This project enabled me to build a complete design system for Equinoxe and iterate quickly based on real communication needs. Beyond visual consistency, the positive feedback from the team — especially regarding the clarity of the templates and the Twitch broadcast assets — highlighted the efficiency and scalability of the system. With more time, I would push the motion dimension further to strengthen the dynamic aspect of the brand across social and live formats. This case study set a strong foundation, and it opened a clear path for how I want to refine, expand, and elevate my approach to identity systems moving forward.

Bus.brief1: Eleven million people. Eleven million lives pushed further away from the digital world — and, little by little, from society itself. For some, an internet connection simply doesn't exist. For others, the equipment is unaffordable, or the screen feels intimidating. The outcome is isolation, and rights people give up on because they don't know how — or are unable — to access them.
Bus.brief2: The Secours Catholique created the Fraternibus to go towards these individuals, directly where they live. A solidarity bus travelling across rural areas and “white zones” to listen, support, guide… and rebuild human connection.
Bus.brief3: Our mission was to design a visual identity that feels warm, accessible, and reassuring — something that makes people want to approach the bus, step inside, share a coffee, or ask a question. We designed the Fraternibus bus livery and two local communication supports to announce its arrival and carry one clear message:
Bus.brief4: “No one should face the digital world alone.”
Bus.cibles2: Three groups directly affected by the digital divide.
Bus.cibles3: Geographically isolated — Cut off from essential services by distance and “white zones”.
Bus.cibles4: Socially isolated — Feel alone with procedures and don't know who to turn to.
Bus.cibles5: Low digital confidence — Little or no equipment, lost with online tools and procedures.
Bus.perso1: Three representative profiles of the people the Fraternibus aims to support.
Bus.perso2: Michelle (79) — Retired, living in a white zone with no means of transport, and not confident using digital tools.
Bus.perso3: Luc (19) — Student in a precarious situation, relying only on a smartphone for studying and for completing administrative procedures that are now 100% online.
Bus.perso4: Cédric (42) — Experiencing severe precariousness and unstable housing, with difficulties accessing rights and employment-related support systems.
Bus.ref2: We drew on two major movements: Impressionism (light, landscapes, readable atmospheres) and Fauvism (bold colours, strong contrast), aligning with Secours Catholique's palette.
Bus.ref3: Henri Manguin — Warm hues and luminous landscapes for a welcoming visual presence.
Bus.ref4: Wassily Kandinsky — Lines and shapes to suggest links and connections.
Bus.ref5: Henri Matisse — Flat colour and formal simplicity to maximise long-distance legibility.
Bus.search2: We first mapped the problem, audiences and use cases with a mind map (access, equipment, guidance, signage).
Bus.search3: Then we explored the metaphor of links/cables — a simple way to depict guidance and connection between isolated people and the Fraternibus.
Bus.search4: Three avenues emerged: 1) continuous lines guiding the gaze, 2) modular segments to pace the bus surface, 3) more organic paths evoking roads and routes.
Bus.compo2: We evolved the initial concept of links/cables into a landscape illustration — warmer and easier to read from a distance.
Bus.compo3: The countryside naturally became the main setting: it reflects the areas the Fraternibus travels through, where isolated people live. Houses are connected by lines symbolising guidance and support.
Bus.compo4: The composition was designed to flow across both sides of the bus: the visual starts near the front with the logo and extends along the vehicle to create a continuous scene.
Bus.colo2: We built a palette combining warm and cool tones, rooted in Secours Catholique's brand colours to ensure coherence and recognition.
Bus.colo3: Warm hues bring proximity, humanity and warmth — encouraging people to approach the bus and start a conversation.
Bus.colo4: Cool tones convey trust, reliability and guidance, echoing the Secours Catholique visual identity.
Bus.colo5: This extended palette allowed us to create a vibrant illustration while maintaining strong long-distance readability on the bus and across all communication supports.
Bus.mascot2: We created a mascot to embody the warm and human spirit of the Fraternibus. It helps make the first contact softer, less intimidating, and gives a symbolic face to the support offered.
Bus.mascot3: Its design is intentionally simple and non-identifiable — no age, no gender, no specific origin. The goal is for everyone to feel included, or at least not excluded.
Bus.mascot4: The mascot reinforces friendliness, welcome and conversation — key elements that encourage people to ask for help, share a coffee, or simply step inside the bus.
Bus.livrables2: We designed a cohesive set of communication tools to make the Fraternibus visible, welcoming and easy to understand — before and during its visit.
Bus.livrables3: The Fraternibus livery plays the central role: a long-distance readable illustration flowing across both sides of the bus to create visual continuity. The links connect houses and guide the eye, symbolising support.
Bus.livrables4: To reinforce its presence on the ground, we created two proximity tools:
Bus.livrables5: • Flyers (front/back) — Distributed ahead of the visit in local shops and community spots, and also on site. A warm and simple layout encouraging people to come have a coffee, talk, and discover the services offered.
Bus.livrables6: • Bus-stop flag — A light visual marker to attach to bus shelters and signal the Fraternibus arrival. Short message, clear pictogram, brand colours: visible without visual clutter.
Bus.livrables7: Together, these three deliverables form a human, readable and complementary ecosystem: the bus attracts, the flag guides, the flyer reassures and informs.
Bus.ccl2: This project reminded us of the value of clear and accessible communication: if the message isn't understood within seconds, it won't connect.
Bus.ccl3: Turning human support into visual identity required finding the right balance between warmth and clarity.
Bus.ccl4: Finally, we realised that communication tools only work when they meet people where they are — in their own towns, routines and daily spaces.
